The Act is titled the "5-Star Generals Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The United States Army Command and General Staff College, established in 1881, has been instrumental in educating and training officers for 127 years. It has significantly impacted battlefields by equipping officers with essential skills for effective command and staff actions, contributing to the nation's success in conflicts and preserving its freedoms. The United States Army Command and General Staff College, the oldest military staff college in the nation, lacks a commemorative coin to celebrate its history and the service of its graduates in war and peace. Located in the American heartland, it continues to educate officers from all branches of the military, as well as members of the civil government and allied nations. The Command and General Staff College Foundation is dedicated to promoting excellence in the faculty and students of the United States Army Command and General Staff College. They seek to educate citizens about the selfless service of military officers and instill pride in military leadership. The Command and General Staff College Foundation is a nongovernmental organization that supports the United States Army Command and General Staff College through funding from members, donations, and grants. They aim to provide the Margin of Excellence to the College's programs and activities for the educational needs of the Nation's field grade officer corps. The Foundation is currently in the initial stages of its first capital campaign to support the College. The Command and General Staff College Foundation is in the initial stages of its first capital campaign to support the College. Five 5-Star Generals who attended or taught at the College include Douglas MacArthur, George C. Marshall, Henry "Hap" Arnold, Dwight D. Eisenhower, and Omar N. Bradley. MacArthur was a distinguished soldier, scholar, and strategist who served for sixty-one years, commanding the 42d Division in World War I and later serving as Chief of the Army General Staff. General MacArthur, awarded the Medal of Honor for defending the Philippines, famously declared "I shall return" before leading forces to victory against Japan. He oversaw the reconstruction of Japan after accepting their surrender and served as the first commander of United Nations Forces during the Korean War. Son of General Arthur MacArthur, he spent time at Ft. Leavenworth as a child and later taught as a Captain. General George C. Marshall, known as the "Organizer of Victory," had a distinguished career in the Army, serving as a Captain in the Field Engineering School and later as the adjutant, quartermaster, and commanding officer of the 3d Engineer Battalion. He entered the Army from the Virginia Military Institute in 1902 and was regarded as one of the most talented staff officers in the United States Army during World War I. During World War II, General George C. Marshall was recognized as one of America's greatest military leaders and played a key role in directing the Allied Powers to victory. He later served as Secretary of State for the United States and was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his European Recovery Program. General Henry H. Arnold, known as "Hap," was the only officer in U.S. history to hold the ranks of General of the Army and General of the Air Force. He graduated from West Point in 1907 and received pilot training from the Wright brothers in 1911. General Henry H. Arnold, also known as "Hap," was a strong advocate for air power and held numerous flying records, including the first delivery of United States mail by air. His contributions heavily influenced accomplishments in World Wars, particularly in World War II, where massed air power played a crucial role in battles and denied the enemy mobility on the ground. One of his citations praised his leadership in guiding the mightiest air force in history. General Arnold's leadership guided the mightiest air force in history. General Dwight D. Eisenhower had a distinguished career in military and civil leadership, leading the invasion of North Africa during World War II and later becoming the Supreme Allied Commander for the invasion of Europe. General Dwight D. Eisenhower led the largest combination of land, sea, and air forces in history during World War II. He was instrumental in the development of NATO and later became the 34th President of the United States. Eisenhower also served as a tactical instructor officer and student at Ft. Leavenworth. General Omar N. Bradley, a distinguished military leader, was recognized for his exceptional leadership and tactical skills. He developed the officer candidate program at the Infantry School, commissioning over 45,000 combat leaders in World War II. Bradley successfully commanded various military units and played a crucial role in defeating German forces in North Africa and Sicily. General Omar N. Bradley's successful career as a field commander peaked when he greatly assisted in the liberation of Europe as commander of the 12th Army Group, which had the largest number of American soldiers under one commander. He later became the Army Chief of Staff in 1948 and the first Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in 1949. Additionally, he attended the Command and General Staff College at Ft. Leavenworth in 1928-1929. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins in limited quantities to honor the 5-Star Generals' graduation from the Command and General Staff College. The coins minted under this Act shall weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and meet specifications for half dollar coins. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act includes portraits of Generals George C. Marshall, Douglas MacArthur, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Henry "Hap" Arnold, and Omar N. Bradley. Each coin will have a value designation, the year "2013", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consulting with the Command and General Staff College Foundation and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of the coins minted under this Act includes portraits of Generals George C. Marshall, Douglas MacArthur, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Henry "Hap" Arnold, and Omar N. Bradley. Each coin will have a value designation, the year "2013", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consulting with the Command and General Staff College Foundation, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Mint facilities will be designated for striking proof and uncirculated coins. The Secretary can only issue these coins during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2013. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Command and General Staff College Foundation to support the college. The Foundation will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may exceed the specified amounts. No surcharge may be included for issuing any coin under this Act if it would exceed the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance on this limitation.
